videoTitle: A tasty, filling, high-protein dish that's easy to prepare and can be taken to work for lunch
videoDescription: Greek Meatballs with Lemon Pasta Ingredients Meatballs 16 oz ground chicken 1 egg ½ cup low-fat feta cheese, crumbled 1.5 tsp dried oregano 1 tsp onion, garlic, thyme, parsley, powder Pinch pepper 1 tsp olive oil Pasta 1.5 cups cooked short-cut legume pasta (lentils, chickpeas) 1 lemon, zest and juice 2 tablespoons olive oil ½ teaspoon dried oregano ¼ teaspoon dried dill ½ teaspoon garlic powder Preparation 1. In a bowl, mix all the meatball ingredients with your hands. Make 12 meatballs. 2. In a frying pan, heat the oil and cook the meatballs until they are golden and cooked, approximately 8 minutes. 3. In another bowl, add the cooked pasta, along with the rest of the ingredients. Mix everything very well. 4. Divide the pasta into 4 portions and place 3 meatballs on top of each one. Ready to enjoy! Makes 4 servings of 3 meatballs each. Total preparation time is 30 minutes. #MontefioreEinstein #MontefioreEinstein #EasyRecipe #HealthyFood #RecipeOfTheDay

videoTitle: Montefiore Einstein Launches HAI Pump Program to Target Liver Cancer with Precision Chemotherapy
videoDescription: The Hepatic Artery Infusion (HAI) pump program at Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center has officially launched! This advanced therapy delivers high dose chemotherapy directly to the liver, targeting liver metastasis, mostly from colon and rectal cancers, and intra-hepatic cholangiocarcinoma. Our first two patients had successful pump placement surgeries with our surgical oncology and colorectal surgeons, two weeks ago. They are home and doing well. They have already started treatment with our medical oncology teams. This is world-class care and we’re proud to continue bringing the most advanced treatment options to our patients. #MontefioreEinstein #MontefioreEinsteinComprehensiveCancerCenter #MECCC #HepaticArteryInfusionPump #HAIPump #Cholangiocarcinoma #ColonCancer #LiverCancer

videoTitle: Recognizing Early Multiple Sclerosis (MS) Symptoms and Why It’s Important Not to Ignore Them
videoDescription: MS affects the brain and spinal cord, often starting between the ages of 20 and 40. The symptoms can vary, but here are some of the key early signs to watch for: - Vision problems: Blurry vision, eye pain, or trouble seeing colors clearly—often a sign of optic neuritis. - Fatigue: Unexplained exhaustion that doesn’t improve with rest. - Numbness and tingling: Particularly in limbs, this can be a warning sign of nerve damage. - Muscle weakness and stiffness: Difficulty walking or experiencing muscle spasms or tightness. If you notice any of these signs, consult your healthcare provider. Early detection and treatment can help manage symptoms and slow disease progression. #MontefioreEinstein #MultipleSclerosis #MSAwareness #NeuroHealth #EarlyDetection #HealthcareMatters

videoTitle: Craving something hearty and healthy? This plant-based chili is packed with bold flavors
videoDescription: Craving something hearty and healthy? This plant-based chili is packed with protein, fiber, and bold flavors. Perfect for a cozy dinner or meal prep for the week! Ingredients: - 1 tbsp + 2 tsp extra-virgin olive oil - 1 medium-large sweet potato, peeled and diced - 1 large onion, diced - 4 cloves garlic, minced - 2 tbsp chili powder - 4 tsp ground cumin - ½ tsp ground chipotle pepper powder - ¼ tsp salt - 2½ cups water - 2 (15 oz) cans black beans, rinsed - 1 (14 oz) can diced tomatoes - 4 tsp lime juice - ½ cup chopped fresh cilantro Directions: 1. Heat oil in a Dutch oven over medium-high heat. Sauté sweet potato and onion until softened (about 4 minutes). Add garlic, chili powder, cumin, chipotle pepper powder, and salt; stir for 30 seconds. 2. Pour in water and bring to a simmer. Cover, reduce heat, and cook until sweet potatoes are tender (10-12 minutes). 3. Stir in beans, tomatoes, and lime juice; simmer for 5 minutes. Remove from heat and mix in cilantro. Serve hot with your favorite toppings like avocado, sour cream, or tortilla chips. Enjoy! #VegetarianChili #HealthyEating #Montefiore #PlantBased #EasyRecipes #MeatlessMeals

videoTitle: Hearty tomato soup with beans and greens
videoDescription: There’s nothing like a warm bowl of soup to keep the chill away! This hearty tomato soup with beans and greens is not only delicious but packed with nutrients to fuel your day. Perfect for lunch or dinner, it’s a comfort food classic with a healthy twist. Ingredients: - 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil - 1 large onion, chopped - 4 cloves garlic, minced - 1 tablespoon tomato paste - 1 teaspoon Italian seasoning - ¼ teaspoon crushed red pepper - 2 (15-ounce) cans no-salt-added white beans, rinsed - 4 cups low-sodium vegetable broth - 1 (28-ounce) can no-salt-added diced tomatoes - 6 cups chopped kale or spinach - ¼ teaspoon salt Directions: 1️⃣ Heat oil in a large pot over medium heat. Add onion and cook until softened, about 5 minutes. Stir in garlic, tomato paste, Italian seasoning, and crushed red pepper. Cook for 1 minute. 2️⃣ Add beans, broth, and tomatoes. Bring to a boil, reduce heat, and simmer for 10 minutes. 3️⃣ Use a spoon to mash some of the beans in the pot to thicken the soup. Stir in greens and salt. Simmer until the greens are tender, about 5 minutes more. 4️⃣ Serve hot and enjoy your cozy, nutrient-packed meal! Who’s ready for a soup night? 🥄 #MontefioreEinstein #Montefiore #HealthyEating #TomatoSoup #ComfortFood #WellnessEats #SoupSeason

videoTitle: This season, consider cozying up inside with a warm, delicious bowl of Rosemary White Bean Soup
videoDescription: This season, consider cozying up inside with a warm, delicious bowl of Rosemary White Bean Soup. Known for its very distinctive aroma, rosemary is also an antioxidant and anti-inflammatory that can provide a boost to your immune system during colder months. Ingredients: - 2 cups dried white beans - 6 cups of water - 1 medium onion, chopped - 4 cloves of garlic - 2 bay leaves - A pinch of salt - A pinch of pepper - Olive oil - 1 tablespoon chopped fresh rosemary Directions: 1. Rinse the beans and place them in a pot along with the water, onion, garlic, and bay leaves. 2. Cover and simmer over low heat for approximately 1 hour until beans are tender and soft. 3. After the beans are cooked, immediately place them in an ice bath to prevent them from continuing to cook and overcooking. 4. Remove the bay leaves. 5. Add the cooked beans to a blender. For a chunkier texture, keep some beans unblended. 6. Liquefy until you get a creamy texture. 7. Season with salt and pepper to taste. 8. Serve the soup on a plate and add a dash of olive oil and rosemary to taste. 9. Enjoy! #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #Food #HealthyFood #RecipeOfTheDay #EasyRecipeOfTheDay #LoHud #lohud_food

videoTitle: 💓 Atrial Fibrillation (AFib): Know the Risks, Protect Your Heart! 💓
videoDescription: Did you know that AFib is the most common irregular and rapid heart rhythm—and a leading cause of stroke? Other AFib risks include: · Heart failure: AFib can weaken the heart, making it difficult to pump enough blood to the body. · Dementia: Recent studies have shown a link between AFib and dementia. · Blood clots: During AFib, blood pools and clots can form in the heart, which can travel to the brain and cause a stroke. If you or someone you know may be at risk, call 1-718-920-5949 or visit the link in the comments. #MontefioreEinstein #MontefioreEinsteinHeart #PulseDay #PulseDay2025 #EuropeanSocietyOfCardiology #HeartHealth #CheckYourPulse #ArrhythmiaAwareness #StayHeartSmart

videoTitle: ❤️ Five Heart Health Must-Haves ❤️
videoDescription: Your heart is a vital organ that keeps your body functioning. Even if you already have heart disease, you can benefit from making healthy choices in your life. Here are Five must-haves to improve your heart health. 1️⃣ Follow a Healthy Diet: Eat more fruits, veggies, whole grains, and lean proteins while cutting back on salt, fats, and fast food. 2️⃣ Exercise: Aim for 30-60 minutes of moderate activity most days, and add stretching and weight training to your routine. 3️⃣ Stop Smoking: Quitting smoking is one of the best ways to protect your heart. 4️⃣ Learn to Relax: Manage stress through deep breathing, hobbies, and a positive outlook. 5️⃣ Monitor Your Health: Work with your doctor to manage blood pressure, cholesterol, and overall heart health. 💡 Small changes can lead to a healthier heart and a healthier you! To learn more, visit the link in the comments. #MontefioreEinstein #MontefioreEinsteinCardiology #HeartHealth #HeartMonth #HeartMonth2025 #HeartHealthMonth #Montefiore #HeartCare

videoTitle: Breakfast for the Heart—Start Your Day with Heart-Healthy Flavor!
videoDescription: Breakfast for the Heart—Start Your Day with Heart-Healthy Flavor! videoTitle: Boost Your Brainpower with Crossword Puzzles This Winter
videoDescription: Snowed in or too cold to go out? Cozy up with a crossword puzzle! This brain-boosting activity comes with serious benefits: 🧩 Strengthen Memory: Crossword puzzles activate multiple brain areas, which could help recall words and facts more easily. 🧠 Reduce Brain Shrinkage: Studies have shown that regular puzzlers experience less brain shrinkage over time. 👥 Social Connection: Gather around the fire with friends or family and solve puzzles to keep your mind sharp while building bonds with loved ones. ⚡ Sharpen Focus: Concentrating on clues improves attention and mental clarity. videoTitle: Keep Your Joints Happy This Winter ❄️
videoDescription: Keep Your Joints Happy This Winter ❄️ Did you know as the temperature drops, those with sensitive joints or conditions like rheumatoid arthritis (RA) may experience stiffness and pain. But cold weather doesn’t have to mean achy joints! Here’s how to stay comfortable and pain-free when temperatures drop: 🔹 Stay Warm: Layer up with gloves, a scarf, and warm socks, use hand warmers, or snuggle under an electric blanket. Heat = happy joints! 🧤 🔹 Move Gently: Stay active with joint-friendly exercises like yoga or swimming. Loosen up with stretches before heading out into the cold. 🧘‍♂️ 🔹 Try Heat Therapy: Soothe sore spots with heating pads or a paraffin bath. Warmth works wonders! 💆‍♀️ 🔹 Mind Your Weight: Maintaining a healthy weight helps reduce strain on your joints. Try starting your day with warm lemon water or a soothing cup of tea to stay hydrated and support your health. 🥗 Other tips: Get plenty of sleep, eat nutrient-rich foods, and avoid heavy lifting to give your joints the care they deserve. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #JointHealth #WinterWellness #StayActive #HealthyLiving

videoTitle: A Heart-Healthy Snack for Game Day
videoDescription: A Heart-Healthy Snack for Game Day This Super Bowl Sunday, enjoy the festivities without compromising your health goals. This guacamole recipe is the perfect addition to your snack table, packed with heart-healthy fats and bursting with flavor. Whether cheering for your favorite team or just there for the commercials, you can feel good about every bite! Ingredients 5 ripe avocados 1/2 cup red onion, finely diced 1 jalapeno, finely diced, taste for heat 1/3 cup fresh cilantro, finely chopped 2 limes, juiced 1 tsp coarse salt kosher salt Instructions - Finely chop the red onion, jalapeno, and cilantro, and set aside. - Scoop the flesh of the avocados into a large bowl and mash using a potato masher or a fork. - Add red onion, jalapeno, cilantro, juice of 1 lime, and 1/2 the salt. Continue to mash and stir. - Taste for seasoning. Add the other lime and a bit more salt if needed. - Top with additional cilantro, and serve immediately. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #SuperBowl #Guacamole #Avocados #EatHealthy #HealthyRecipes

videoTitle: Glaucoma: Act Early, Act Now
videoDescription: Glaucoma: Act Early, Act Now 🕶️ While glaucoma has no cure, practice these steps to reduce your risk and protect your vision: ✔️ Eye Exams: Start screening early and often for the disease and monitor your eye pressure. ✔️ Exercise: It’s good for your heart and your eyes, but make sure it’s low impact to avoid raising eye pressure. ✔️ Eye Protection: Sunglasses aren’t just stylish; they shield your eyes from harmful UV rays. ✔️ Healthy Diet: Fruits and veggies contain vitamins and minerals that support eye health, especially in food form. ✔️ Family History: Glaucoma often runs in families; share this information with your doctor. Don’t wait—start caring for your eyes today! Learn more in the link in the comments below. #GlaucomaPrevention #HealthyVision #EyeCareTips #MontefioreEinstein #WellnessMatters #GlaucomaAwarenessMonth

videoTitle: Lentil Minestrone Soup Recipe
videoDescription: Nothing is more appealing during these cold days than a warm and hearty bowl of soup. Today, we’re sharing a favorite recipe – an easy-to-make and flavorful lentil soup. Lentil Minestrone Soup Ingredients: 1 tablespoon olive oil ¾ cup onion, diced 1 cup of carrot, diced small (about ¼ in) ½ cup of celery, diced small 1 cup of potato, diced small 3 garlic cloves, minced 4 cups of diced fresh tomato 2 cups of any lentils of your choice 4 cups low-sodium vegetable broth 1 teaspoon dried basil ½ teaspoon dried oregano ½ teaspoon dried thyme 2 cups green leafy vegetables, spinach or Swiss chard, or a combination of both Preparation: 1. Heat the oil in a soup pot. Add the onion, carrot, celery, potato, and garlic. 2. Cook for about 8 minutes or until vegetables are tender. 3. Add the tomato, lentils, broth, and dried herbs. 4. Reduce the heat to medium-low, cover the saucepan, and simmer. for 30 to 35 minutes. Make sure to stir occasionally. 5. Add the leafy greens and cook for 8 more minutes or until wilted. This recipe makes 6 servings. Total preparation time is 60 minutes. Servings: 6 #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #Food #HealthyFood #EasyRecipeOfTheDay #EasyRecipe

videoTitle: What is Glaucoma? Know the Risk Factors and Protect Your Vision with Early Detection
videoDescription: What is Glaucoma? Glaucoma is a group of serious eye conditions that damage the optic nerve, causing permanent vision loss. Over three million Americans have glaucoma, yet half are unaware. Early stages often have no symptoms. You can lose up to 40% of your vision before noticing something is wrong. Risk Factors include: 👉 Age: More likely to develop glaucoma after age 60 👉 Family History: Greater possibility ifi glaucoma runs in the family 👉 Health Conditions: Diabetes or severe nearsightedness increase chances 👉 Ethnicity: More prevalent among African Americans and Hispanic individuals Early detection is critical—protect your vision by getting regular eye exams! To learn more, visit the link in the comments below. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #GlaucomaAwareness #EyeHealth #VisionCare #HealthyLiving

videoTitle: Protect Yourself from Cervical Cancer: Screening & Prevention Tips You Need to Know
videoDescription: Did you know that cervical cancer is the 4th most common cancer in women worldwide? It disproportionately impacts individuals in under-resourced communities. The good news? There’s a vaccine that can protect you from the most common cause of cervical cancer: infection with the human papillomavirus (HPV). However, regular screening with a Pap test (also called a Pap smear) remains crucial. Screenings can help detect HPV infections, inflammation, or early signs of cervical cancer. Your age helps determine the best screening plan for you. According to the National Cancer Institute (NCI): - Women aged 21-29: It is recommended to get your first Pap test at age 21 followed by Pap testing every three years. - Women aged 30-65: Choose one of the following screening options: - An HPV test every five years - A combined HPV/Pap test every five years - A Pap test every three years Women over 65: Speak with your doctor to determine if you still need regular screenings. This depends on factors such as your health history. Don’t wait—schedule your screening today! Call (833) 632-2623. To learn more about cervical screening visit the link in the comments below. #MontefioreEinsteinComprehensiveCancerCenter #CervicalCancerAwarenessMonth #MontefioreEinstein

videoTitle: Beat the Winter Blues: Tips to Combat Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD)
videoDescription: Feeling down as the days get shorter? Seasonal Affective Disorder (SAD) is a type of depression triggered by reduced sunlight in the fall and winter. Less light can disrupt your mood, energy, and sleep patterns. Symptoms can include: - Low energy - Trouble sleeping or oversleeping - Difficulty concentrating - Changes in appetite or weight But there are ways to combat SAD. Try light therapy, stay active, and spend time outdoors during daylight hours. If symptoms persist, don’t hesitate to seek support—your mental health matters. 🌞❄️ #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #SeasonalAffectiveDisorder #MentalHealth #psyciatryandbehavioralhealth #MEPA #SADAwareness #Wellness
tags: Montefiore,Montefiore Health System,Montefiore Medical Center,Montefiore Hospital,Hospital,Bronx
caption: false

videoTitle: Beat travel fatigue and jet lag during the holidays!
videoDescription: The holiday season, one of the busiest times of the year to travel, can result in travel fatigue—temporarily feeling exhausted or mentally drained—particularly after a long flight or road trip. Jet lag on the other hand, is the result of traveling across time zones and can cause symptoms such as sleeplessness, anxiety, loss of appetite and headaches. This season, try the following tips to help combat jet lag: - Limit alcohol and caffeine before and during your travel - Pack a travel sleep kit with an eye mask, earplugs, and comfy clothes. - Drink plenty of water throughout your journey - Adjust your sleep schedule before your trip: Go to bed 1-2 hours earlier if traveling east, or 1-2 hours later if heading west. This helps your body adapt to the new time zone more smoothly. Don’t let sleepless nights ruin your holiday adventures. Take steps to prioritize your rest and wake up ready to enjoy this season to the max! #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #TravelTips #BetterSleep #HealthyTravel #SleepWell #Travel

videoTitle: Celebrating Dr. Susan Coupey: A Tribute from the Children’s Hospital at Montefiore Einstein
videoDescription: Dr. Coupey was an early leader in developing the subspecialty of adolescent medicine. Her focus has been on adolescent mental health, chronic health conditions and reproductive health. After fellowship, Dr. Coupey joined the Montefiore Einstein faculty and rose to the rank of Professor of Pediatrics in 1993. She has received the Harry F. Gordon Award for Outstanding Clinical Teaching, and the William Obrinsky Award for Excellence in Student Teaching. From 2002 to 2018, Dr. Coupey served as Chief of the Division of Adolescent Medicine. During this time she oversaw a doubling of the faculty in the Division and developed new clinical programs including the Long-acting Reversible Contraception (LARC) Program, the Eating Disorder Program, and the Gender Care Program. From 1989 through 2007 Dr. Coupey was Director of the Introduction to Clinical Medicine (ICM) Program and as course leader for three required medical school courses, teaching medical interviewing, doctor/patient relationship, and physical diagnosis skills. Dr. Coupey served on the Board of Directors of the Society for Adolescent Health and Medicine and as President of the Board of Directors of the North American Society for Pediatric and Adolescent Gynecology. In 2005, she was honored with the Adele Dellenbaugh Hofman Award by the American Academy of Pediatrics. She was inducted into the Leo M. Davidoff Society, elected to Alpha Omega Alpha by Einstein students and selected by the Board of Governors of the Alumni Association as Honorary Alumna of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Coupey has trained many leaders in the field of adolescent medicine, who are now educating the next generation of adolescent medicine specialists across the United States, as well as abroad. Congratulations to Dr. Susan Coupey Recipient of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore Einstein 2024 Career Achievement Award! videoTitle: 4 Toy Safety Tips Every Parent Should Remember this Holiday Season
videoDescription: Toys are a fun, magical part of the holiday season, but they’re also an important part of a healthy childhood. Toys and creative play help children develop essential cognitive, social, and motor skills, along with self-confidence. But what makes a toy safe? - Look for the instructions and safety information. Phrases like “nontoxic,” “BPA-free,” and, on electric toys, “UL Approved,” help ensure you’re buying safe toys. - Beware of choking hazards: Younger kids — especially those under 3 — instinctively put things in their mouths. - Use helmets or protective gear when recommended - It’s important to clean toys regularly, especially when cold, flu, RSV, and COVID-19 are circulating. These simple steps can make playtime both fun and safe! For more toy safety tips, see the link in the comments below. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #ToySafety #HaveFunBeSafe #FamilyWellness #HealthTips

videoTitle: Are you looking for a special treat that is healthy and delicious? Try Walnut Brownies.
videoDescription: Are you looking for a special treat that is healthy and delicious? Try Walnut Brownies. These brownies are suitable for any celebration, such as holidays, birthdays, anniversaries, or just when you crave a sweet bite. Keep this recipe on hand to ensure you can cure your sweet cravings with a nutritious treat. You are going to love it! #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #Brownies #WalnutBrownies #HolidayTreat #Dessert Ingredients: 2 cups of fresh seedless dates (soak them in warm water for 10 minutes if they are dehydrated) 1/4 cup almond butter 3 tablespoons unsweetened applesauce 1/3 cup unsweetened cocoa powder 1/4 cup dark chocolate with at least 70% cocoa in pieces or chocolate chips 1/3 cup chopped walnuts Preparation: 1. Preheat the oven to 350º F. 2. Use a mold for baking bread and line the inside surface with the baking paper. 3. In a food processor, crush the dates. 4. Add the almond butter and the applesauce to the crushed dates. Process until incorporated well. 5. Add the chocolate and the crushed nuts to the mixture and mix well with the rest of the ingredients. 6. Transfer the mixture to the mold and spread it in a uniform layer. 7. Bake for approximately 15 minutes until the edges are slightly dry. 8. Remove from the oven and let cool for 10 minutes. 9. After 10 minutes, carefully remove it from the mold. Do not remove the baking paper. 10. Let it cool on a plate for at least 30 minutes; the colder, the firmer the brownies will be. 11. Cut it into 10 portions. Total preparation time: 40 min. Makes 10 servings.

videoTitle: Continuous Glucose Monitors (CGMs) track blood sugar levels in real-time
videoDescription: Continuous Glucose Monitors (CGMs) track blood sugar levels in real-time through a device attached to your body. This technology has transformed the glucose monitoring experience for many—from multiple finger pricks per day to simply checking an app on your phone. CGMs also give you real-time feedback on how different foods and activities affect your blood sugar levels. Talk to your doctor today to see if a CGM is right for you. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #DiabetesAwarenessMonth #Diabetes #Type2Diabetes #ContinuousGlucoseMonitor #CGM #MontefioreEinsteinEndocrinology

There’s clinical evidence to suggest that live music of any kind (not just concerts) not only physically and emotionally excites us, but can be used to treat: Pain Depression Alzheimer’s If conventional approaches have not been working for your condition, consider supplementing with music therapy. This involves doctor assisted instrument playing as a means of engaging the limbic system to encourage better healing. If this sounds like something that interests you, speak with your provider. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #MusicAsMedicine #Music #MusicTherapy

videoTitle: How to help reduce the risk of Alzheimer’s
videoDescription: Memory changes can naturally come with aging, but being mindful of brain health is key. Discuss any concerns with your healthcare provider; a simple memory test can help identify early signs of dementia. To help reduce Alzheimer’s risk, try incorporating these healthy habits: - Read regularly to keep your brain sharp - Challenge yourself with puzzles to stimulate cognitive function - Stay socially active to support mental well-being - Maintain a balanced diet and exercise for overall brain health Taking small, mindful steps now can make a difference over time. #MontefioreEinstein #MontefioreEinstein #Alzheimers #HealthyAging #HealthyLifestyle

videoTitle: The Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center’s Lymphedema Program was recently recognized!
videoDescription: Lymphedema is an abnormal buildup of lymph fluid under the skin. It can happen to anyone but is especially common in people who have been treated for cancer. The swelling and skin problems from lymphedema can change the way a person looks and feels day to day. We are honored to announce that Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center’s Lymphedema Program was recently recognized for its “highest quality of care for people living with lymphatic diseases” by an organization dedicated to education, research, and advocacy — the Lymphatic Education & Research Network Conservative Care Center of Excellence! To learn more about what causes lymphedema, how to identify it, and steps you can take to prevent it, please visit the link below in the comments. #MontefioreEinstein #MontefioreEinsteinComprehensiveCancerCenter #MECCC #LymphedemaProgram #LymphaticDisease

videoTitle: Hands Clean, Health Strong
videoDescription: Many disease-causing germs — such as Salmonella, E. coli, norovirus, and others — can remain on your hands after you use the toilet or change a diaper, or even handle raw meat. videoTitle: Critical flu symptoms to watch for
videoDescription: As flu season approaches, it's important to remember that while the flu is a common seasonal illness, it can still pose serious health risks. If you experience any of the following symptoms, you should seek help at an emergency room or urgent care center immediately: - Respiratory difficulties - Severe vomiting or diarrhea - Signs of extreme dehydration - Those over 65 and children under 5, pregnant women, and people with preexisting medical conditions are at higher risk for complications #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #Flu #StayHealthy #HealthyLifestyle

videoTitle: 5 fun ways to help you stay injury-free and run like a pro!
videoDescription: Today, let’s rally to support everyone taking on the #NYCMarathon! Keep an eye out for our own Children's Hospital at Montefiore (CHAM) runners, and give them a big shout as they tackle the course. 🏅👟 Feeling inspired to start your own running journey? Here are 5 fun ways to help you stay injury-free and run like a pro! 💪💨 1️⃣ Warm Up! – Kick off every run with a dynamic warm-up to get those muscles primed. Say goodbye to cold starts! 🥶🔥 2️⃣ Strength Training is Key – Think runners don’t lift? Think again! Building strength helps your body handle those tough miles. 💥💪 3️⃣ Switch Things Up! – Keep it interesting! Take to the trails, bike or go swimming to keep things fun and avoid burnout. 🚴‍♀️🏊‍♂️ 4️⃣ Catch Those Z’s – Recovery is EVERYTHING! Prioritize sleep to help your body repair and come back even stronger. 💤✨ 5️⃣ Fuel Up Right – Great runs start in the kitchen! Give your body the good nutrition it needs to stay energized every mile. 🥗🥑 #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #NYC #Marathon #CHAM #RunStrong #RunSmart #InjuryFreeRunning #ChildrensHospitalAtMontefiore

videoTitle: Our physical therapists evaluate and implement rehabilitation programs for people of all ages
videoDescription: Our physical therapists evaluate and implement rehabilitation programs for people of all ages coping with physical limitations caused by injury, illness or surgery. As part of the therapeutic process you will receive a range of treatments that may include: - Manual therapy (hands-on mobilization of soft tissue) - Therapeutic modalities, such as ultrasound, electrical stimulation and traction - Neuromuscular re-education - Gait Training Widely recognized for its excellence in rehabilitation care, our department has been honored with the Outstanding Center for Physical Therapy Clinical Education Award from the New York/New Jersey Clinical Education Consortium. When your doctor prescribes physical therapy, our friendly and accommodating staff will help you arrange an appointment at a time that is convenient for you. We will do everything we can to make your visit as easy and comfortable as possible. To schedule your appointment, please call us at 718-920-4083 for our Moses campus, 718-405-8410 for our 1500 Blondell Ave office, or 718-920-9171 for our Wakefield campus. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #NationalPhysicalTherapyMonth

videoTitle: The older we get, the more important it is to take efforts to keep our spine in good shape.
videoDescription: The older we get, the more important it is to take efforts to keep our spine in good shape. Here are a few habits you can adopt to promote a healthy spine: - Avoid standing for long periods - Wear cushioned soles in your shoes - Use a stool under your feet while sitting so that your knees are higher than your hips - If sitting for long periods, make sure to stand up and walk around periodically To learn more, visit Montefiore Einstein’s Spine Center in the link below in the comments. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #SpineHealth #HealthyBack #HealthyHabits

videoTitle: A todos les encanta un regreso. Paul Rivera consiguió un nuevo pulmón y una nueva vida.
videoDescription: El laureado actor Paul Giamatti cuenta la historia de Paul –otro Paul– un héroe de la vida real y su increíble regreso gracias a un trasplante de pulmón en Montefiore Einstein. Paul era uno de esos ciudadanos ejemplares que mantiene viva a nuestra ciudad. Hasta que un día le sobrevino una fibrosis pulmonar, seguramente a causa de ciertas sustancias químicas en su lugar de trabajo. La enfermedad era incurable. Su única esperanza era un trasplante de pulmón. Mientras otros hospitales lo rechazaban, solo uno, Montefiore Einstein, dio el paso adelante. A Paul le consiguieron un nuevo pulmón y una nueva vida. Vea a Paul Giamatti contar la historia de Paul Rivera, y obtenga más información: https://montefioreeinstein.org/es/stories/paul For more Montefiore Einstein content, follow us on social at: • Facebook (Eng) – https://www.facebook.com/montefioremedicalcenter • Facebook (Spa) – https://www.facebook.com/MontefioreObjetivoTuSalud • Twitter (Eng) – https://twitter.com/montefiorenyc?lang=en • Instagram (Eng) – https://www.instagram.com/montefiorehealthsystem/ • Instagram (Spa) – https://www.instagram.com/montefioreobjetivotusalud/?hl=en • LinkedIn (Eng) — https://www.linkedin.com/company/montefiore-health-system

Dr. Rubinstein is a chair of the CARRA Mental Health Workgroup and an active member of the CARRA community, has authored numerous research publications, and is dedicated to research that aims to improve the mental health and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) disease outcomes in youth. This award honors her outstanding efforts and achievements to advance pediatric rheumatology research and improve the lives of children living with pediatric rheumatic and related autoimmune diseases. #MontefioreEinstein #ChildrensHospitalAtMontefioreEinstein #MontefiorePeds #Pediatrics #PediatricRheumatology #SLE #carrainc

videoTitle: Everyone Loves a Comeback. Paul Rivera Got a New Lung and a New Life
videoDescription: Award-winning actor Paul Giamatti tells a story about Paul—a different Paul—a real-life hero who made the ultimate comeback with the help of a lung transplant from Montefiore Einstein. Paul was one of those hardworking citizens who keep our fair city going. But then he got struck with pulmonary fibrosis, probably as a result of chemical exposure on the job. It was untreatable; his only hope was a lung transplant. While others turned him down, only one hospital, Montefiore Einstein, showed up to help. They got Paul a new lung, and they gave him a new life. videoTitle: Montefiore Einstein, along with the Bronx Children’s Museum, hosted a special Family Day.
videoDescription: Montefiore Einstein, along with the Bronx Children’s Museum, hosted a special Family Day with a theme of “Prescription to Play.” The event, which was free and open to Montefiore Einstein associates and their families, emphasized the importance of healthy, active lifestyles through play and community engagement. The event marked the inaugural “Walk with ME (Montefiore Einstein)” Parade, where children will march around the museum playing musical instruments before the museum closes. This new daily event aims to foster community spirit, encourage active participation, and provide a finale to the museum experience for children and their families. Additionally, guests witnessed the unveiling of the Montefiore Einstein Mile, “Montefiore Mile” within the museum, a pathway denoted by markers to encourage movement and play, emphasizing that wellness is about both physical activity and mental engagement. This event was in partnership with Montefiore Einstein's Office of Community Affairs, Office of Diversity and Inclusion, and Children's Hospital at Montefiore Einstein. Learn more in the link below. #MontefioreEinstein #ChildrensHospitalAtMontefioreEinstein #MontefiorePeds #Pediatrics #WalkWithME #MontefioreMile @bronxchildrensmuseum #BronxTimes

videoTitle: This light, flavorful salad makes the perfect accompaniment for anything you’ve got on the grill!
videoDescription: This light, flavorful, and nutritious salad makes the perfect accompaniment for anything you’ve got on the grill this summer! Greek Orzo Salad Ingredients 3 tbsp red wine vinegar 2 tbsp fresh lemon juice 1/3 cup olive oil 1/2 tsp garlic powder 1 tsp dried oregano 1/2 tsp kosher salt 16 oz orzo pasta, wheat or gluten-free 1/2 cup halved pitted kalamata olives, plus 2 tablespoons brine 1/3 cup red onion, diced small 3 cups from 1 large English cucumber, diced small 1 pint grape tomatoes, halved 1 orange bell pepper, diced 1/2 cup feta cheese, cubed fresh oregano, optional garnish Instructions - Bring a large pot of salted water to a rolling boil. Add the orzo and cook according to package directions for al dente, adding an extra minute. - Drain and rinse under cold water, drain. - Meanwhile, In a large bowl, combine the dressing ingredients. Add the olives, red onion and brine from the olives and mix to combine. - Stir in the pasta with the cucumber, tomatoes and bell pepper and toss well. Taste for salt and adjust as needed. - Add the cheese just before it is ready to serve. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #OrzoSalad #SummerSalad #EatHealthy #Summer2024

videoTitle: Grilled Watermelon Pizza can be a refreshing summer snack, appetizer, or treat.
videoDescription: Grilled Watermelon Pizza can be a refreshing summer snack, appetizer, or treat. Full Recipe: - 2 watermelon slices, 1.5 inches thick - 2 tablespoons of extra virgin olive oil - A pinch of salt - A pinch of pepper - 1 cup of blueberries - 1 cup cherry tomatoes cut in half - ½ cup shredded low-fat mozzarella cheese Prep: 1. Preheat a grill or grill pan. 2. Brush the oil on both sides of the watermelon slices and season with salt and pepper. 3. Grill the watermelon slices on one side for 2 minutes, then flip it over and cook for another 2 minutes. 4. Remove the slices from the grill and cut them into 4 slices each. Then, place the blueberries, tomatoes, and cheese on top. 5. Finish with a drizzle of olive oil on top. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #Watermelon #Pizza #SummerFun #SummerRecipes

videoTitle: Easy, creamy, tasty, and HEALTHY, hummus makes the perfect snack
videoDescription: Easy, creamy, tasty, and HEALTHY, hummus makes the perfect snack or appetizer when paired with a whole wheat pita or raw veggies. See below for the recipe. Ingredients: 1½ cups cooked chickpeas, drained and rinsed ⅓ cup smooth tahini 2 tablespoons extra-virgin olive oil 2 tablespoons fresh lemon juice, more to taste 1 garlic clove ½ teaspoon sea salt 5 tablespoons water, or as needed to blend paprika, red pepper flakes, or parsley, for garnish warm pita bread , and/or veggies, for serving Prep: 1. In a high-speed blender, place the chickpeas, tahini, olive oil, lemon juice, garlic, and salt. Use the blender baton to blend until very smooth, adding water as needed to blend, and/or to reach your desired consistency. 2. Transfer to a serving plate, top with desired garnishes and serve with warm pita and veggies, as desired. #Food #HealthyFood #EasyRecipe #RecipeOfTheDay #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein

videoTitle: Meet Dr. Suzette Oyeku: Chief of Academic General Pediatrics at Children’s Hospital at Montefiore
videoDescription: Meet Suzette O. Oyeku, MD, MPH Chief, Academic General Pediatrics; General Pediatrician, Children's Hospital at Montefiore Einstein Professor of Pediatrics; Clinician-Investigator, Child Health Advocate, Albert Einstein College of Medicine Since 2016, Dr. Oyeku has served as Chief of the Division of Academic General Pediatrics, which has 63 faculty. The Division staffs over 35,000 outpatient visits and over 3,000 inpatient admissions each year. Dr. Oyeku is a clinician investigator with expertise in health services research and implementation science. Her work focuses on improving patient outcomes for children with chronic diseases such as sickle cell disease and also reducing health inequities. She is an ordained deacon at Grace Baptist Church (Mount Vernon, NY). Working with the Conference of National Black Churches/Institute of Church Administration and Management, Dr. Oyeku trained faith-based leaders across the US to help increase vaccine confidence and acceptance in diverse communities. Dr. Oyeku was a founding member and co-leader of the Leadership, Engagement, Advocacy and Diversity Education and Residency (LEADER) Program) Program at CHAM, which received the 2023 Academic Pediatric Association (APA) Education Award. During the first year of the COVID-19 pandemic, Dr Oyeku & Dr. Miguelina German, organized and raised funds to secure basic items such as diapers, formula and clothes for families who were financially struggling in the Bronx. Dr. Oyeku is frequently featured in local and national news media, sharing health information about child health wellness and health care issues. videoTitle: Zucchini Date bread recipe
videoDescription: Looking for tasty gluten-free dessert bread with no added sugar? Look no further than Zucchini Date bread. See below for ingredients and prep! #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #HealthyRecipe #ZucchiniBread #Zucchini #Dates #Recipe #ZucchiniDateBread Ingredients: 1½ cups oat flour (gluten free) (182g) ½ cup gluten-free all-purpose flour (rice flour mix) (77g) ½ teaspoon baking soda 1 teaspoon baking powder ½ teaspoon salt 1 teaspoon ground cinnamon 1 medium sized zucchini, grated (about 1½ cups worth) 2 eggs 4 ounces applesauce, no sugar added ¼ cup date syrup (77ml) 5 medium Medjool dates, chopped ½ cup almond milk or other dairy-free milk (120ml) Preparation: 1. Preheat the oven to 350°F. Lightly oil a bread pan and set it aside. 2. Next, pit and chop the dates. Then use a cheese grater to grate the zucchini, until you have about 1½ cups worth. Set both aside. 3. In a large bowl or stand mixer bowl, add the eggs, applesauce, and date syrup. Mix until combined. Stir in the grated zucchini and chopped dates. 4. Next, add the almond milk or other dairy-free milk and mix. 5. Then add the oat flour, all-purpose flour, baking powder, baking soda, salt, and ground cinnamon. Use the mixer attachment or hand mixer to blend it all together until the batter is nice and smooth. 6. Pour the batter into the bread pan and bake it on the middle oven rack for 1 hour or until it is browned and the top springs back when touched. 7. Let the bread cool. Prep time: 20 minutes Cook time: 1 hour Servings: 10

videoTitle: High blood pressure is the single most important treatable risk factor for stroke.
videoDescription: High blood pressure is the single most important treatable risk factor for stroke. Here are some ways you can lower it: - Eat a healthy diet rich in whole grains, healthy proteins, and a variety of fruits and vegetables while avoiding saturated fats - Decrease your intake of sodium, alcohol, and caffeine - Reduce stress and get plenty of sleep - Get regular exercise and maintain a healthy weight Your healthcare team should be regularly measuring your blood pressure, or you can purchase an inexpensive self-measuring blood pressure monitoring device for home use. To learn more about stroke prevention, risks, treatments, and support services and resources, visit us at the link below. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #StrokeAwarenessMonth #TakeAction #HealthyHabits #HealthyLifestyle #StopStrokeBeforeItStarts #strokecenter
tags: Montefiore,Montefiore Health System,Montefiore Medical Center,Montefiore Hospital,Hospital,Bronx
caption: false

videoTitle: Diabetes or prolonged high glucose levels in the body can increase your risk for stroke
videoDescription: Diabetes or prolonged high glucose levels in the body can increase your risk for stroke. Some ways you can manage your glucose are to: - Prepare healthy meals, rich in a variety of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, and lean meats. Avoid saturated fats and high-sugar desserts. - Maintain an active lifestyle. Enjoy a variety of exercises like walking, biking, swimming, dancing, and yoga. Grab a friend and try something new! - Manage your stress levels and mental health. - Measure your blood sugar regularly, and take all medications as prescribed by your doctor. For more information on stroke prevention, risks, treatments, and support services and resources, visit us at the link below. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #StrokeAwarenessMonth #TakeAction #HealthyHabits #HealthyLifestyle #StopStrokeBeforeItStarts #StrokeCenter

videoTitle: Are raisins nature’s candy or a nutrient-packed powerhouse? Why not both?
videoDescription: Are raisins nature’s candy or a nutrient-packed powerhouse? Why not both? Let's break it down: - Packed with fiber, antioxidants, and minerals like iron and potassium. - Perfect in salads, oatmeal, or yogurt for a natural sweetness. - Moderation is key due to high sugar and calories. *Since dried fruit is more concentrated in calories and sugar, aim for a moderate ¼ cup serving. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #HealthyFood #NationalRaisinDay #Raisins

videoTitle: 5 Tips for Women's Eye Health
videoDescription: Did you know women face a higher risk of diseases like age-related macular degeneration or AMD, cataracts, and glaucoma? That's why it's crucial for women to adopt healthy habits to lower the chances of developing preventable vision impairments. ● Get a comprehensive eye exam at age 40 (consult your doctor to find out what kind would be right for you) ● Know your family history — it helps assess your risk for certain conditions ● Eat healthy foods with lots of Vitamins A, C, E and Omega-3 ● Don't smoke — tobacco use can even affect your eyes ● Wear sunglasses even on cloudy days! #WomensHealth #HealthyEyes #HealthyGirl #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein

videoDescription: Montefiore Einstein is accelerating access to life-altering medications with its new, state-of-the-art specialty pharmacy in Westchester. videoTitle: Cinco de Mayo Corn Salad Recipe
videoDescription: Whip up a vibrant Cinco de Mayo Corn Salad with this easy recipe. Full recipe: 2 (16 ounce) bags frozen sweet corn (thawed) 2 large fresh tomatoes, roughly chopped (Creole) or 2 cups grape tomatoes, halved 1 vidalia onion, finely chopped 1⁄2 cup fresh cilantro, chopped 1⁄4 cup extra virgin olive oil 1 lime, juice of 1 (14 ounce) can black beans, drained and rinsed Salt and pepper (use Kosher or Sea salt and freshly cracked pepper for a fresh flavor) Prep: 1. Mix all ingredients and toss to blend. 2. (Can be made 2 hours ahead. Let stand at room temperature, tossing occasionally). #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #CincoDeMayo #HealthyFood #HealthyLifestyle

videoTitle: Thai Fish Curry
videoDescription: This recipe is as tasty for your palette as it is healthy for your heart. It contains heart-healthy ingredients such as fish, olive oil, curry, and vegetables. Thai Fish Curry is a delicious option with the slowly poached fish in a flavorful coconut curry sauce. #Montefiore #MontefioreEinstein #HealthyRecipe #Recipe #Thai #ThaiRecipe #ThaiFishCurry #ThaiFish #Curry #HealthyCurry Thai Fish Curry Ingredients: 1 tablespoon extra-virgin olive oil 1 cup onion, finely chopped 3 cloves of garlic, crushed 1 tablespoon fresh ginger, chopped, or ½ teaspoon powder 3 tablespoons Thai curry paste (red, green, yellow), or 2 teaspoons curry powder 2 cups unsweetened coconut milk 1 tablespoon fish sauce or low-sodium soy sauce ½ teaspoon brown sugar or honey 1 tablespoon lemon juice ½ cup green beans, cut in half ½ cup red pepper, cut into strips ½ cup carrot, diced 21 oz white fish or salmon, cut into approximately 2-inch cubes 2 tablespoons fresh cilantro, chopped (alternative parsley-optional) Preparation: In a saucepan, heat the oil. Add the onion and cook until transparent. Then, add the garlic, ginger, and curry. Stir and cook for 2-3 additional minutes. Add coconut milk, fish or soy sauce, lemon, sugar, or honey. Reduce heat to medium-low and cook for 10-12 minutes until sauce thickens slightly. Next, add the green beans, cook for 3 minutes, and add the peppers and carrot. Cook for three additional minutes. Finally, add the fish to the saucepan. Cook for 4-6 minutes or until cooked through. Sprinkle the cilantro or parsley on top, if desired. Ready, enjoy! Makes 4 servings Total preparation time 35 minutes

videoTitle: Celebrating Dr. Daphne Hsu: A Tribute from the Children’s Hospital at Montefiore Einstein
videoDescription: Meet Daphne T. Hsu, MD, one of the nation's leading experts in children's heart failure and heart transplant. From 2007 to 2021, Dr. Hsu served as Chief of the Division of Pediatric Cardiology at the Children's Hospital at Montefiore (CHAM). She expanded the Division's clinical programs and developed multi-disciplinary clinics for the care of pediatric and adult congenital heart disease. In 2009, the Division established its ACGME-accredited pediatric cardiology fellowship program. She was responsible for the training for dozens of future pediatric cardiologists. Dr. Hsu has served as Past-president and board member of the Pediatric Heart Transplant Study Group, the Pediatric Cardiomyopathy Registry and the Adult Congenital Heart Disease Committee for the American Heart Association. She served on the Sub Board of Pediatric Cardiology of the American Board of Pediatrics. Dr. Hsu has treated more than 600 children with heart failure and more than 250 children undergoing heart transplant. videoTitle: Guy Monseair’s Heart Stopped Twice—the City Island Rowing Coach Was Back Coaching Days Later
videoDescription: How do you thank someone for saving your life? When my heart stopped twice after not one, but two life-threatening cardiac arrests, it was a race to save my life. Dr. Michler got it right, he said, “I’m going to get you back on the coaching launch in 10 days.” Sure enough, just 10 days after an emergent bypass surgery, I was back on the coaching launch. How incredible is that? I technically died. But here I am. I’ve been given a second chance. I could not have been in better hands. videoTitle: The NYC Research & Improvement Networking Group (NYC RING) 20th Annual Convocation of Practices
videoDescription: The New York City Research and Improvement Networking Group (NYC RING) hosted its 20th annual convocation of practices. NYC RING is a practice-based research network (PBRN) that engages primary care providers in all phases of the research process. videoTitle: Celebrating Dr. Steve Shelov: A Tribute from the Children’s Hospital at Montefiore Einstein
videoDescription: Dr. Shelov was instrumental in the founding of The Children's Hospital at Montefiore. In 19 years as Director of Resident Education and Program Directorship, Dr. Shelov was responsible for training approximately 800 pediatric residents at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine/Montefiore Medical Center. In addition, Dr. Shelov was responsible for overseeing the pediatric education of 4000 Albert Einstein College of Medicine medical students. Dr. Shelov authored two books, Caring for Your Baby and Young Child, (5 million copies in circulation) and The First Year of Life (one million copies in circulation) which received awards for lay education by numerous magazines, national surveys, and parent organizations. From 1983 to 1987, Dr. Shelov was the Pediatrician for The Today Show, a nationally televised news program. Dr. Shelov educated the public on a variety of issues concerning children's health and wellness. Congratulations to Dr. Steve Shelov Recipient of the Children's Hospital at Montefiore 2023 Alumni Career Achievement Award! videoTitle: Linfedema: Síntomas y reducción de riesgos
videoDescription: El linfedema es una inflamación crónica que afecta a ciertas personas en tratamiento contra el cáncer a las que se les extirpan los ganglios linfáticos o reciben radioterapia. A veces estas terapias dificultan el drenaje adecuado del sistema linfático. El linfedema puede desarrollarse cerca de la parte del cuerpo en la que se ha realizado el tratamiento. Este video de Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center describe qué causa el linfedema y cómo determinar si se está desarrollando, así como los pasos a seguir para prevenir el empeoramiento de esta condición. Además, incluye medidas de cuidado personal, como una serie de ejercicios para hacer en casa y cambios de estilo de vida que reducen el linfedema o ayudan a prevenirlo. En este video también se describen algunas estrategias con las que tu proveedor puede ayudarte, desde rastrear la acumulación de líquido linfático con un dispositivo especial a una cirugía para aliviar la inflamación. Descubre cómo la gente con linfedema, con la colaboración de su equipo de salud, aplica estas estrategias para manejar el linfedema y gozar de una vida plena. ▬ Contenido de este vídeo ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬ 00:00 Tu sistema linfático 01:17 Qué es el linfedema? 02:05 Signos y síntomas del linfodema 03:11 Reducir el riesgo del linfedema 05:12 Ejercicios para reducir el riesgo de linfedema 06:19 Qué hacer y qué no hacer en el cuidado personal 08:41 Beneficios de in estilo de vida saludable For more Montefiore Einstein content, follow us on social at: • Facebook (Eng) – https://www.facebook.com/montefioremedicalcenter • Facebook (Spa) – https://www.facebook.com/MontefioreObjetivoTuSalud • Twitter (Eng) – https://twitter.com/montefiorenyc?lang=en • Instagram (Eng) – https://www.instagram.com/montefiorehealthsystem/ • Instagram (Spa) – https://www.instagram.com/montefioreobjetivotusalud/?hl=en • LinkedIn (Eng) — https://www.linkedin.com/company/montefiore-health-system

videoTitle: Lymphedema: Symptoms and Lowering Risk
videoDescription: Lymphedema is a chronic swelling that happens to some people being treated for cancer who get their lymph nodes removed or receive radiation therapy. These therapies can make it hard for the body’s lymphatic system to drain properly. Lymphedema can develop near the part of the body that was treated. This Montefiore Einstein Comprehensive Cancer Center video describes what causes lymphedema, how to figure out if lymphedema is developing, and steps you can take to help prevent lymphedema from getting worse. It includes self-care steps such as at-home exercises and lifestyle changes that can lessen or help prevent lymphedema. The video also describes what your healthcare provider can do to help, such as tracking lymphatic fluid buildup with a special scale and performing surgery to relieve swelling. Learn how people with lymphedema, in partnership with their healthcare team, can use these strategies to manage their lymphedema and enjoy full lives. ▬ Contents of this video ▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬▬ 00:00 Your Lymphatic System 01:19 What is Lymphedema? 02:06 Signs and Symptoms of Lymphedema 03:11 Reducing Risk of Lymphedema 05:15 Exercises for Lymphedema Risk Reduction 06:21 Self-Care Do’s and Don’ts 08:43 Benefits of a Healthy Lifestyle For more Montefiore Einstein content, follow us on social at: • Facebook (Eng) – https://www.facebook.com/montefioremedicalcenter • Facebook (Spa) – https://www.facebook.com/MontefioreObjetivoTuSalud • Twitter (Eng) – https://twitter.com/montefiorenyc?lang=en • Instagram (Eng) – https://www.instagram.com/montefiorehealthsystem/ • Instagram (Spa) – https://www.instagram.com/montefioreobjetivotusalud/?hl=en • LinkedIn (Eng) — https://www.linkedin.com/company/montefiore-health-system

videoTitle: Pampered and Empowered: BOLD Beauty Day Brings Self-Care and Support to People Facing Cancer
videoDescription: Cancer diagnosis and treatment can have far-reaching impacts on a person’s body, mind and spirit—and a caring community is considered by many to be an essential source of emotional support. Knowing that looking good is a big part of feeling good , the Montefiore Einstein Cancer Center’s BOLD Beauty Day 2023 welcomed 39 women for complimentary makeovers, facials, and hand exfoliation and moisturization treatments as well as for an opportunity to select a wig and the latest styles in fashion. GLAM4GOOD, Croom Boutique, Hair We Share, Mary Kay and SOUL RYEDERS were among the local businesses and nonprofits that donated beauty products and staffing for the event. In addition, a catered lunch, provided by the American Cancer Society, was served by BOLD interns and staff. videoTitle: Webinar #6 - Menstrual Bleeding in Adolescent Girls – Elizabeth Alderman, MD & Jennifer Davila, MD
videoDescription: In our sixth continuing medical education webinar, Chief of the Division of Adolescent Medicine Elizabeth Alderman, MD, FAAP, FSAHM and Co-Director of the Hemophilia and Thrombosis Treatment Program Jennifer Davila, MD presented about menorrhagia (menstrual bleeding that lasts more than 7 days) including diagnostic criteria, when a bleeding disorder should be considered, the underlying disorders that can cause this condition, and hormonal as well as hematological management. For reference, Drs. Alderman and Davila see patients at the following location: Children’s Hospital at Montefiore Girls and Bleeding (GAB) Clinic 3415 Bainbridge Ave. Bronx, NY 10467 Phone number for Dr. Alderman’s practice: 718-654-6692 Phone number for Dr. Davila’s practice: 718-741-2342 The next webinar will occur on Thursday August 8, 2023 at 6:00pm EST on Zoom. The topic will be Sickle Cell Disease and the Brain: Understanding School Difficulties and Mental Health Challenges, presented by Kaitlin Strumph, DO. Dr. Strumph is Associate Professor of Pediatrics in the Division of Pediatric Hematology, Oncology, and Cellular Therapy at the Children’s Hospital at Montefiore and Albert Einstein College of Medicine. videoTitle: Webinar #5 - Enhanced Primary Care for the NICU Graduate – Deborah E. Campbell, MD
videoDescription: In our fifth continuing medical education webinar, Chief of the Division of Neonatology and Medical Director of the Low Birth Weight Infant Evaluation and Assessment Program (LEAP) Deborah E. Campbell, MD presented best practices for treating children in the primary care setting who previously were hospitalized in the NICU. Dr. Campbell identified some of the continuing health and developmental care needs of high-risk infants after neonatal intensive care, discussed the evolution of the neurodevelopmental and neurobehavioral outcomes as well as later functioning over the life course for these patients, and provided guidance on how primary care pediatricians can help the families of these patients based on perspectives shared by parents. For reference, Dr. Campbell sees patients at the following location: Montefiore Weiler Hospital Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) 1825 Eastchester Road Bronx, NY 10461-2301 Phone: 718-904-4105 The next webinar will occur on Wednesday July 12, 2023 at 6:00pm EST on Zoom. The topic will be menstrual bleeding in adolescent girls: too much or too often, and will be jointly presented by Elizabeth Alderman, MD, FAAP, FSAHM and Jennifer Davila, MD. Dr. Alderman is Chief of the Division of Adolescent Medicine at the Children's Hospital at Montefiore and Professor of Pediatrics, Obstetrics and Gynecology, and Women's Health at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Dr. Davila is Co-Director of the Hemophilia Treatment Program at the Children's Hospital at Montefiore and Associate Professor of Pediatrics at Albert Einstein College of Medicine. Register for the Zoom link at https://bit.ly/MontefiorePedsWebinar6. videoTitle: Community Conversations—An Open Forum for Bronx Dialogues on Cancer
videoDescription: A chance to talk about cancer with Montefiore Einstein Cancer Center (MECC) oncologists and other experts brought some 30 Bronx residents to the first Community Conversations town hall at the Dreiser Community Center in the Bronx on December 13, 2023. Designed to empower, educate and enlighten residents, cancer peer navigators and cancer specialists through open dialogue, participants were free to ask multiple questions. The conversation also enabled the MECC team and peer navigators to learn what’s on the mind of people in the community regarding cancer risk, diagnosis and care. videoDescription: The Montefiore Einstein Community Affairs team completed another successful Healthy Holiday Fresh Produce Distribution Initiative, with 60,000 pounds of fresh produce distributed to local residents of the Bronx, Westchester and the Hudson Valley. videoDescription: "When the prize is our future, every day is the match of our lives. In all my years of playing around the world, I have never seen a brighter soul than Chiara's. videoTitle: Montefiore Einstein Administers First Doses of COVID-19 Vaccine to Children Ages 6 Months - 5 Years
videoDescription: Another momentous day at Montefiore Einstein! Children’s Hospital at Montefiore (CHAM) and Montefiore Medical Group (MMG) administered our first doses of the COVID-19 vaccine for children ages 6 months to 5 years—a critical step in the continued efforts to stop the spread of the coronavirus. “I think this is a huge milestone because now we can get our youngest patients, and often the most vulnerable patients, vaccinated…I couldn’t recommend it more highly,” said Lauren Roth, MD, MMG, Comprehensive Family Care Center. videoDescription: It was a monumental day at Children’s Hospital at Montefiore (CHAM) on November 3, 2021 — Montefiore-Einstein administered its first doses of the COVID-19 vaccine to eligible children ages 5-11, a critical step in efforts to stop the spread of the coronavirus. “Kids and families in the Bronx were really hit very hard with the pandemic so we are particularly excited to be able to provide this opportunity to keep the kids and families here safe and to prevent the spread of COVID-19 disease to get kids back to school and back to their normal lives.” — Patricia A. videoTitle: Montefiore-Einstein's Annual Healthy Thanksgiving Fresh Produce Distribution
videoDescription: Montefiore-Einstein’s Community Relations team along with key sponsors hosted three fresh produce distribution events at Lehman College, Hostos Community College and Montefiore Mount Vernon, to help families in the communities we serve this Thanksgiving addressing the social determinant of food insecurity. Volunteers helped package and distribute the healthiest options of produce for families. The team did an incredible job, increasing from 10,000 pounds of fresh produce distributed in 2020 to 40,000 pounds distributed this year and feeding 4,000 families in the Bronx and lower Westchester! We are grateful to all of our partners who help make these events successful. #MontefioreMountVernon #MontefioreEinstein #Thanksgiving #Produce #HealthyFood #CommunityRelations
tags: Montefiore,Montefiore Health System,Montefiore Medical Center,Montefiore Hospital,Hospital,Bronx
caption: false

videoTitle: Objetivo: Tu Salud - Un programa sobre las vacunas contra el COVID-19 de Montefiore-Einstein
videoDescription: ¿Tienes preguntas sobre las vacunas contra el COVID-19? Sintoniza nuestro programa "Objetivo: Tu Salud" sobre las vacunas contra este virus. Es producido por Montefiore-Einstein y presentado por el Dr. Eliscer Guzmán quien junto a otros expertos como el jefe de cardiología, el Dr. Mario García, nos cuentan su propia experiencia cuando se vacunaron y contestan tus dudas y preguntas sobre estas vacunas. videoTitle: Montefiore-Einstein Supports NYPD Blue Chips Youth Basketball Event

Featured guest, legendary NY Knicks player Charles Smith joined Marcos Crespo, SVP Community Affairs, Montefiore-Einstein; Juanita N. Holmes, Chief of Patrol, NYPD; and Darcel Clark, Bronx District Attorney, for this important co-ed youth mentoring and sports program impacting the lives of thousands of youth across the City and building stronger bonds between youth and police.

videoTitle: Gestione su salud en línea con Montefiore MyChart
videoDescription: Montefiore MyChart es gratis y accesible las 24 horas del día, 7 días a la semana, desde cualquier computadora, tableta o smartphone a través de la web de MyChart o aplicación móvil, y está disponible en inglés y español. Con Montefiore MyChart puede: • Pedir citas, programarlas y cambiarlas • Enviar mensajes seguros a su médico • Ver y pagar facturas ordinarias o electrónicas de manera segura • Configurar planes de pago • Ver resultados de tests • Pedir reposiciones de recetas • Hacer un registro previo a la cita (PreCheck-In) • Actualizar información médica, personal y de plan de seguro • Administrar la atención médica de un dependiente o familiar mediante autorización (proxy access) Descubra cómo empezar a utilizar Montefiore MyChart.
tags: Montefiore,Montefiore Health System,Montefiore Medical Center,Montefiore Hospital,Hospital,Bronx
caption: true

videoTitle: Manage your Healthcare Online with Montefiore MyChart
videoDescription: Montefiore MyChart is free and accessible 24/7 from any computer, tablet or smartphone via the MyChart website or mobile app, and available in English and Spanish. With Montefiore MyChart you can: • Schedule, reschedule, or request appointments • Send secure messages to your doctor • View and pay bills securely, including paperless billing • Set up payment plans • Check test results • Request prescription refills • PreCheck-In for upcoming appointments • Update personal information, insurance and medical information • Manage the healthcare of a dependent or family member through Proxy Access Find out how to get started with Montefiore MyChart today.

videoTitle: State of Gratitude: A Tribute to the Healthcare Heroes Saving New York
videoDescription: Starting in the spring of 2020, every evening at 7:00PM, New Yorkers clapped, cheered and banged pots and pans in support of the healthcare workers fighting to save lives. This holiday season, in tribute to their bravery and resilience, we brought together the #OrchestraoftheBronx, @EveryVoiceChoirs, Brooklyn United Music & Arts Program (@bkunitedmb), and New Yorkers to show our gratitude to the healthcare heroes saving New York. Special thanks to @NatalieMerchant whose song—‘Kind and Generous’—is the inspirational backbone of our State of Gratitude tribute #MontefioreEinstein #StateOfGratitude #7PMTribute #HealthcareHeroes #Montefiore #MonteHeroes

videoTitle: Montefiore-Einstein gathered in solidarity and reflection for #WhiteCoatsforBlackLives
videoDescription: On June 5, 2020 Montefiore-Einstein gathered in solidarity and reflection taking a stand on systemic racism as a public health crisis promoting justice for all. In memory of George Floyd and countless others, we observed 8 minutes and 46 seconds of silence. Montefiore-Einstein has a long history of fighting against social and racial injustice—a fight that rages on. @EinsteinCollegeofMedicine #WhiteCoatsForBlackLives #GeorgeFloyd #RacismAsAPublicHealthCrisis #Equality #EqualityInMedicine #JusticeForAll @JohnLegend @Common @Rhymefest @SonyMusic @Universalmusicgroup@BMGMusic @ReachMusic (Song Credit: Glory (From the Motion Picture Selma) by Common & John Legend)

videoTitle: Monteﬁore presenta Corazón Film (Español) | Ana de Armas, Demian Bichir (HD)
videoDescription: Una película que además de robarte el corazón te mostrará cómo conservarlo. Protagonizada por Ana de Armas, actriz nominada al Golden Globe (Knives Out) y Demian BIchir, nominado al premio Oscar (A Better Life). Está dirigida por John Hillcoat, nominado a la Palme d’Or y el guión es de Kelly Sane. Los hombres que pagan por el cuerpo de Elena Ramírez no saben que su corazón está fallando. Sin nada que perder y una familia que la necesita viva, decide dejar Santo Domingo y seguir a un doctor a un viaje casi imposible a Nueva York. Basado en la historia real de una paciente de Montefiore. Ofrece tu corazón https:\\www.donatelife.net https:\\www.doingmoremonteﬁore.org Presentada por: Monteﬁore Duración: 48 minutos Idiomas: Inglés y Español Actores: Demian Bichir, Ana de Armas Director: John Hillcoat Guión: Kelley Sane Género: Drama, Independiente
tags: Montefiore,Montefiore Health System,Montefiore Medical Center,Montefiore Hospital,Hospital,Bronx,Ana de Armas,Corazón,Película Corazón,Tribeca film,Tribeca film festival,Demian Bichir,Cardiología,Trasplante de corazón H,LVAD,John Hillcoat,Cirugía del corazón,Donación de órganos,Festival Internacional de Cine,Nominado a un Oscar,Golden Globes,Mes del Corazón
caption: false

videoTitle: Montefiore presents Corazón Film | Ana de Armas, Demian Bichir (HD)
videoDescription: A film that doesn't just aim to grab your heart, but keep it. Starring Golden Globe nominee Ana de Armas (Knives Out) and Academy Award nominee Demian Bichir (A Better Life). Directed by Palme d'Or nominee John Hillcoat and written by Kelley Sane. The men who pay Elena Ramirez for her body don't know that her heart is failing. With nothing left to lose and a family that needs her to live, she decides to leave Santo Domingo and follow a doctor on a near-impossible journey to New York. Based on a real-life patient story from Montefiore. Give your heart. https://www.donatelife.net https://www.doingmoremontefiore.org Presented by: Montefiore Running time: :48 Languages: English, Spanish Actors: Demian Bichir, Ana de Armas Director: John Hillcoat Writer: Kelley Sane Genres: Drama, Independent

videoTitle: Montefiore Chair of Rehab speaks about the impact of AposTherapy
videoDescription: Dr. Matthew Bartels, Chairman of the Department of Rehabilitation Medicine at Montefiore Medical Center speaks about AposTherapy potentially being a “paradigm shift.” He says, “Traditionally, we have applied treatments that are short-term fixes that treat symptoms, but not the underlying biomechanics of the condition. Now we have something that will actually retrain an individual to walk and use their muscles so that they can alter the course of their disease.”   The AposTherapy treatment uses a biomechanical shoe-like device that is personally calibrated by your physical therapist to offload pressure from painful joints, thereby relieving your pain. The foot-worn device also introduces mild amounts of perturbation, which can help retrain muscles in your knees, hips and lower back.   A specially-trained physical therapist will conduct an initial evaluation to determine if you are suitable for the AposTherapy 12-month treatment plan. You'll return for five follow-up visits over the course of a year to reassess your condition and recalibrate the device to optimize your results.   Learn more about the AposTherapy treatment offered at Montefiore Medical Center by visiting www.montefiore.org/apos
tags: Matthew Bartels,Dr. Matthew Bartels,Montefiore Medical Center,Montefiore,AposTherapy,Knee pain,Knee osteoarthritis,Knee arthritis,Arthritis knee,Knee exercises,Osteoarthritis,Hip pain,Lower back pain,Hurt knee,Hurt hip,Hurt lower back,Knee treatment,Hip treatment,Lower back treatment,Shoes for pain
caption: false

videoTitle: Science, disguised as a shoe at Montefiore
videoDescription: t started by understanding that altering our interaction with the ground could help millions of people with knee, hip and lower back pain live healthier lives. Now, over ten years later, scientific research has led to a treatment method that addresses the symptoms of your pain by calibrating a biomechanical device you'll wear for about an hour each day. It's amazing how science can disguise itself so well as a shoe. Now offered at Montefiore Medical Center.

videoTitle: Montefiore nurse feels like she has new knees
videoDescription: Cathy, a critical care nurse at Montefiore Medical Center talks about her experience with Montefiore’s new treatment for knee, hip and lower back pain. The AposTherapy treatment uses a biomechanical shoe-like device that is personally calibrated by your physical therapist to offload pressure from painful joints, thereby relieving your pain. The foot-worn device also introduces mild amounts of perturbation, which can help retrain muscles in your knees, hips and lower back.   A specially-trained physical therapist will conduct an initial evaluation to determine if you are suitable for the AposTherapy 12-month treatment plan. You'll return for five follow-up visits over the course of a year to reassess your condition and recalibrate the device to optimize your results.   Cathy explains that she felt like she had new knees. She goes on to say that, “It just gave me this sense of hope because I’ve been struggling with this pain for so long that I just figured I had to live with it. But it’s this feeling now that it’s going to be OK. “   Learn more about the AposTherapy treatment offered at Montefiore Medical Center by visiting www.montefiore.org/apos

videoTitle: Louanne's Story
videoDescription: New York Yankees fan Louanne Mitchell dreamed of taking part in the team’s winter fantasy baseball camp. She was a picture of good health in 2013 when she noticed a small bump on her leg that her dermatologist removed and sent out for routine testing. The results were shocking – metastatic malignant melanoma. Dr. Dan Costin, her oncologist at White Plains Hospital, promised her she would live to realize her dream of attending the New York Yankees Fantasy Baseball camp that winter. She underwent video-assisted thoracoscopic surgery at White Plains Hospital to remove three malignant tumors in her lung, and a few days later was back on her feet and ready to play ball. She continued seeing Dr. Costin, receiving a round of immunotherapy treatments to ensure the cancer had been eliminated. After a year of seemingly great results, it was discovered that the cancer had recurred, this time to her brain. That’s when Dr. Costin brought together an all-star team from both White Plains Hospital and Montefiore Health System, with the help of Dr. Steven Libutti, Director of Montefiore Einstein Center for Cancer Care and a member of the White Plains Hospital Cancer Executive Committee. Dr. Costin quickly picked up the phone to call Dr. Patrick LaSala, a renowned neurosurgeon at Montefiore. Dr. LaSala removed the mass and prescribed a follow-up treatment of stereotactic radiation surgery (SRS), an innovative treatment combination that, along with additional immunotherapy, eliminated the tumor completely. The SRS treatment was performed by Dr. Madhur Garg, Clinical Director of Radiation Oncology and Co-Director of the SRS program at Montefiore. The new White Plains Hospital and Montefiore Health System partnership ensured that Louanne received exceptional, all-star care, close to home, and today, she remains cancer-free. She made it to the Yankees Fantasy Camp – her ultimate dream – and is looking forward to another winning season. The White Plains Hospital and Montefiore Health System Partnership – Stronger Together.
tags: http://www.louannesstory.org

videoTitle: Adult Congenital Heart Disease Care for Adults and Children | Montefiore
videoDescription: Congenital heart defects are the most common type of birth defect; more than 35,000 babies in the United States are born with congenital heart defects, according to the National Institutes of Health. Thankfully, advances in cardiology and cardiac surgery have led to a greater than 90% survival rate. But even children who get immediate treatment require highly—specialized care throughout their lifetimes. We created the Montefiore Adult Congenital Heart Disease (MAtCH) Program in 2009 with our patients in mind. This comprehensive program—the only one of its kind in the New York Metropolitan area—provides seamless, integrative and multidisciplinary health care for children, adolescents and adults living with congenital heart disease. For more information: http://www.montefiore.org/achd

videoTitle: Celebrate Montefiore 2014 | At the Heart of Inspired Healthcare
videoDescription: Montefiore Einstein Center for Heart and Vascular Care is known for its innovation and clinical excellence, offering novel treatments for the most complex cases and advancing the field of cardiovascular care through pioneering research. Directed by internationally acclaimed experts, the Center offers a range of services including cardiac imaging, interventional cardiology, arrhythmia services and the most advanced adult and pediatric surgical care for valve repair, aneurysms and heart failure, and provides some of the best outcomes in the state, including the highest one-year heart transplant survival rate. The Society of Thoracic Surgeons has repeatedly awarded the Center a three star rating for its cardiovascular surgery program, the highest category of quality given to only approximately 12 percent of participating hospitals in the United States and the only heart surgery program in the region to be ranked by Consumer Reports. With an ongoing commitment to research, the Center is fostering breakthroughs in the genetics of heart disease and the application of stem cells to treat heart conditions, and has received a National Institutes of Health multi-million-dollar grant to study improvements in mitral valve repair and atrial fibrillation surgery. For more information: http://www.montefiore.org/gala

videoTitle: Montefiore Partners with the Lopez Family Foundation
videoDescription: Montefiore Medical Center today announced a new partnership with the Lopez Family Foundation and the establishment of the Center for a Healthy Childhood. Designed to promote healthy living through community health programming and messages and a healthy environment, the new initiative builds upon Montefiore’s activities throughout its health system and the community-at-large and Jennifer Lopez’s long-standing commitment to improving the health and well-being of women and children. “My roots are in the Bronx. It was natural to join forces with Montefiore, an organization that has cared for and served the Bronx for more than 100 years,” said Jennifer Lopez. “Our foundation has done amazing work improving the health and well-being of children around the world and now we’re looking forward to expanding the efforts underway in the borough where I grew up.” For more information, visit: http://www.montefiore.org/body.cfm?id=1738&action=detail&ref=1148

videoTitle: Samantha's Story: Endovascular Coiling Procedure
videoDescription: For more information, visit: http://www.montefiore.org/stories-samantha At just 37, while running on the treadmill in her basement, Samantha Sherman began to feel nauseous and dizzy. She recalls trying to shut off the treadmill, but when she awoke on the ground, it was still running. Thinking she had a concussion she went to the ER at a local Greenwich hospital where she learned she had had a stroke. The subarachnoid hemorrhage due to a ruptured aneurysm in her brain was beyond what her local hospital could care for, so a family friend and plastic surgeon recommended she see vascular neurosurgeon, Dr. David Gordon, a specialist at Montefiore dually trained in open and minimally invasive surgery. Once at Montefiore, Dr. Gordon performed an endovascular coiling procedure on Samantha. A guiding catheter was inserted into the femoral artery in her leg, and a microcatheter was then inserted through the guiding catheter into Samantha's ruptured aneurysm. Coils were then inserted through the microcatheter to close off the aneurysm and prevent it from further bleeding. Because she chose to go to the one hospital in the region that can treat very complex neurovascular cases, Samantha was able to avoid the high risk associated with undergoing open surgery to treat an aneurysm located near the brain stem. Thanks to the amazing teamwork of the Departments of Neurological Surgery and Radiology, the treatment was a success. Samantha is now back to the life she loves to live, managing a busy household, taking walks in her neighborhood, spending precious time with her kids--and taking nothing for granted. Montefiore is comprised of the highest caliber neurosurgeons and neuroradiologists. Our physicians use the most advanced procedures to treat patients of all ages suffering from a broad spectrum of often complex and life-threatening conditions such as strokes, aneurysms and vascular malformations. Because of our competence in innovative and minimally invasive techniques, we can often eliminate the need for open surgery. Montefiore is one of a small group of medical centers in the New York metropolitan area, and the only hospital in the Bronx, to offer such state-of-the-art services for complex cases.

videoTitle: Ed's Story | Joint Replacement Surgery at Montefiore Medical Center
videoDescription: Ninety-year-old Ed Tobachnik was not willing to give up those long walks with his wife without a fight. But the severe arthritis in his hip was causing so much pain that Ed's active lifestyle was becoming almost impossible to maintain. Ed saw multiple surgeons in Manhattan and was told he was too old for joint replacement surgery. He was turned away. But Dr. Neil J. Cobelli of Montefiore's Adult Reconstructive/Joint Replacement Surgery department reviewed Ed's case, saw his special determination, and knew he was an excellent candidate for successful hip replacement surgery. Dr. Cobelli performed Ed's surgery, which was followed up by a rigorous course of post-op physical therapy designed by the orthopaedic experts at Montefiore. Today Ed is thrilled with his new total hip replacement. He is back to his normal active life—including long walks with his wife of 65 years. Ed is one more example of why The American College of Surgeons National Surgical Quality Improvement Program (ACS NSQIP®) recognizes Montefiore as achieving exemplary surgical patient care and outcome. Learn more at: www.inspiredmedicine.org Montefiore Medical Center: www.montefiore.org
